title: Sustainable Jet Fuel Microalgae Market | Global Market Analysis Report - 2036
description:
Sustainable Jet Fuel Microalgae Market Forecast and Outlook 2026 to 2036 The sustainable jet fuel microalgae market is projected to reach USD 5.2 billion by 2036, growing at a CAGR of 11.2% from its 2026 valuation of USD 1.8 billion.
Sustainable Jet Fuel Microalgae Market Key Takeaways Metric Value Industry Sales Value (2026) USD 1.8 billion Industry Forecast Value (2036) USD 5.2 billion Industry Forecast CAGR 2026 to 2036 11.2% What Is Driving the Sustainable Jet Fuel Microalgae Market?
Hydrothermal liquefaction (HTL) is the leading technology route in the Sustainable Jet Fuel Microalgae market, accounting for 38% of the market share.
Commercial aviation is the largest end-use segment in the Sustainable Jet Fuel Microalgae market, accounting for 56% of the market share.
In the sustainable jet fuel microalgae market, companies adopt a variety of strategies to maintain a competitive edge.
text:
Sustainable Jet Fuel Microalgae Market Forecast and Outlook 2026 to 2036

The sustainable jet fuel microalgae market is projected to reach USD 5.2 billion by 2036, growing at a CAGR of 11.2% from its 2026 valuation of USD 1.8 billion. Dominant players in this market defend pricing power through advanced production technologies and exclusive access to high-quality microalgae strains, enabling them to set premium prices. Entry barriers are upheld by significant capital investment requirements and the specialized knowledge needed to scale production. Regulatory approvals and long development timelines also limit new entrants, further solidifying the position of established players. Fragmentation in the market persists due to the high level of technological innovation and the growing number of niche players focused on specific applications. However, as larger firms expand their production capacities and acquire smaller innovators, the degree of fragmentation may narrow over time. Ultimately, larger companies are positioned to control more of the market through vertical integration and strategic partnerships.

What is the Growth Forecast for the Sustainable Jet Fuel Microalgae Market through 2036?

The sustainable jet fuel microalgae market is expected to experience robust growth through 2036, driven by the increasing need for eco-friendly alternatives to traditional aviation fuels. The market is projected to grow at a CAGR of 11.2%, with an estimated value of USD 5.2 billion by 2036. This growth is propelled by technological advancements in microalgae cultivation and fuel conversion processes, which are making the production of sustainable jet fuel more economically viable. Additionally, increasing investments in green aviation technologies and growing support from governments for low-carbon aviation fuels will continue to support market expansion.

The next decade will likely see a steady rise in the adoption of sustainable jet fuel derived from microalgae, as airlines and governments work towards achieving environmental goals. By 2036, the market will play a significant role in reducing the carbon footprint of air travel, contributing to the broader efforts to achieve sustainability within the aviation sector. With the aviation industry's focus on environmental responsibility, the demand for sustainable jet fuel will continue to increase, establishing a vital market for microalgae-based biofuels.

Sustainable Jet Fuel Microalgae Market Key Takeaways

Metric Value Industry Sales Value (2026) USD 1.8 billion Industry Forecast Value (2036) USD 5.2 billion Industry Forecast CAGR 2026 to 2036 11.2%

What Is Driving the Sustainable Jet Fuel Microalgae Market?

Historically, the sustainable jet fuel microalgae market developed from early research into biofuels as alternatives to fossil derived aviation fuels. Conventional jet fuel production relied almost exclusively on crude oil refining, which delivered high energy density and established supply chains but posed climate impact concerns. Early biofuel initiatives focused on first generation feedstocks such as vegetable oils and animal fats, which competed with food uses and showed limited greenhouse gas reductions on a lifecycle basis. Microalgae emerged as a promising feedstock because of rapid biomass growth rates and high lipid content, enabling potential conversion into hydrocarbons compatible with existing jet engines. Initial efforts were concentrated in laboratory and pilot scale programs funded by governments and research consortia, aimed at understanding cultivation systems, strain selection, and oil extraction technologies. These initiatives highlighted challenges including high production costs, energy intensive processing, and the need for large scale photobioreactor or open pond infrastructure. Engagement by aircraft manufacturers and regulatory bodies laid the groundwork for certification pathways and fueled incremental investments in demonstration projects.

Future demand for sustainable jet fuel microalgae is expected to be driven by aviation decarbonization mandates, corporate net zero targets, and increasing recognition of lifecycle emissions in airline procurement policies. Airlines and fuel producers are anticipated to accelerate offtake agreements for microalgae derived fuel as governments implement regulations that constrain carbon emissions and incentivize low carbon fuels through credits or blending mandates. Technological advances in strain engineering, nutrient recycling, and integrated biorefinery models are projected to reduce costs and improve yields, making microalgae based jet fuel more competitive with conventional and other biojet alternatives. Expansion of sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) certification and investment in processing facilities that link algae cultivation with carbon capture sources will influence market growth. Remaining challenges include scaling cultivation infrastructure, securing reliable low cost CO2 and water resources, and navigating complex certification for new fuel pathways. Long term market prospects will depend on how effectively the industry demonstrates consistent production at commercial scale, aligns with regulatory frameworks, and integrates into airline fuel supply chains with quantifiable environmental benefits.

What are the Key Segments in the Sustainable Jet Fuel Microalgae Market?

The Sustainable Jet Fuel Microalgae market is divided into technology routes and end uses. The technology routes include hydrothermal liquefaction, transesterification + upgrading, pyrolysis & catalytic cracking, and gasification-based routes, with hydrothermal liquefaction holding the largest market share. On the end-use side, commercial aviation leads the market, accounting for 56% of the share, followed by military aviation, business & general aviation, and other sectors. The rising demand for environmentally sustainable fuel alternatives in the aviation industry is driving the growth of this market. The microalgae-derived jet fuel is seen as a promising solution due to its low carbon footprint and the potential to meet stringent emission regulations in aviation. Key regions driving this market include North America, Europe, and Asia Pacific, where advancements in biofuel technologies and strong governmental policies are fostering the development of sustainable aviation fuels.

What is Driving Growth in the Hydrothermal Liquefaction Technology Route?

Hydrothermal liquefaction (HTL) is the leading technology route in the Sustainable Jet Fuel Microalgae market, accounting for 38% of the market share. HTL is favored due to its ability to convert microalgae biomass directly into a high-quality, renewable fuel that can be used in aviation without requiring significant upgrading or modifications to existing engines. This technology is highly efficient in producing jet fuel with a low carbon footprint, making it an attractive option for the aviation industry, particularly in regions with stringent emissions regulations. The growing demand for sustainable aviation fuels, especially in commercial aviation, is propelling the adoption of HTL. In commercial aviation, which represents 56% of the end-use segment, airlines are under increasing pressure to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and meet sustainability goals. HTL offers a scalable solution, as it can process large amounts of microalgae biomass in a cost-effective manner. Additionally, HTL produces a wide range of biofuels that can be tailored to meet the specific fuel requirements of the aviation industry. The technology is gaining traction in North America and Europe, where several government initiatives and subsidies are supporting the development of sustainable jet fuel. The continued advancement of HTL technology, including improved yields and efficiency, is expected to drive further growth in this segment.

What is Driving the Growth of Commercial Aviation in the Sustainable Jet Fuel Microalgae Market?

Commercial aviation is the largest end-use segment in the Sustainable Jet Fuel Microalgae market, accounting for 56% of the market share. This growth is primarily driven by the aviation industry's need to meet stringent global emissions standards while reducing its reliance on fossil-based fuels. As governments around the world set ambitious carbon-neutral targets, airlines are increasingly adopting sustainable fuel solutions, such as microalgae-derived jet fuel, to reduce their environmental impact. The aviation industry is one of the largest contributors to global carbon emissions, and as the demand for air travel increases, the pressure to find sustainable alternatives grows. Microalgae-based jet fuel offers a viable solution, as it has the potential to significantly reduce lifecycle greenhouse gas emissions compared to traditional jet fuels. In regions like North America and Europe, where regulatory frameworks are encouraging the transition to sustainable aviation fuels, the demand for microalgae-derived jet fuel is expected to rise. Furthermore, advancements in fuel production technologies, such as hydrothermal liquefaction, are making microalgae-derived fuels more economically competitive with conventional jet fuels. The scalability and sustainability of microalgae-based fuels are key factors in driving their adoption in commercial aviation, making them an integral part of the aviation sector’s long-term sustainability strategy.

What are the Key Dynamics in the Sustainable Jet Fuel Microalgae Market?

The sustainable jet fuel microalgae market is gaining momentum as part of the broader effort to reduce carbon emissions and dependence on fossil fuels in aviation. Microalgae-based jet fuel, often produced through the conversion of algae biomass into lipids or hydrocarbons, offers a promising alternative to traditional jet fuel due to its renewable nature and lower carbon footprint. As the aviation industry faces increasing pressure to meet stricter environmental regulations and sustainability targets, microalgae-based biofuels are viewed as an essential solution. The market is driven by technological advancements in algae cultivation, genetic engineering, and fuel conversion processes that improve the economic feasibility and scalability of algae-based jet fuel. The growing demand for sustainable aviation fuels (SAF) and support from global regulatory frameworks further propel market growth.

What are the Key Drivers of Growth in the Sustainable Jet Fuel Microalgae Market?

Key drivers of growth in the sustainable jet fuel microalgae market include the increasing global focus on reducing carbon emissions and achieving net-zero targets in aviation. Governments and international organizations are incentivizing the development and adoption of alternative fuels, including SAF, which provides a direct growth opportunity for algae-based fuels. Advances in algae cultivation techniques, such as optimized photobioreactor systems and genetically modified algae strains, have significantly increased biomass productivity, making the fuel more economically competitive. In addition, the aviation industry's long-term sustainability goals and rising public demand for greener air travel contribute to the growing interest in algae-derived jet fuel. Partnerships between airlines, governments, and biofuel companies are further accelerating research and development to make algae-based jet fuel a mainstream aviation solution.

What are the Key Restraints in the Sustainable Jet Fuel Microalgae Market?

The sustainable jet fuel microalgae market faces several challenges that can hinder its widespread adoption. High production costs are a significant restraint, as large-scale algae cultivation and fuel conversion technologies remain expensive compared to conventional fossil-based jet fuel. The infrastructure required to process algae into jet fuel is still under development, which adds complexity to the market's scalability. Additionally, the efficiency of algae-based fuel production is dependent on factors like nutrient availability, climate conditions, and the development of effective harvesting techniques. The variability in algae yields, along with the large-scale investment needed in both infrastructure and research, poses a barrier to achieving commercial competitiveness. These factors contribute to slower progress toward making algae-derived jet fuel a viable alternative for the aviation sector.

What are the Key Trends in the Sustainable Jet Fuel Microalgae Market?

Key trends in the sustainable jet fuel microalgae market include significant advancements in algae-based biofuel technology and increasing investment in research to optimize algae strains for higher oil yields and better fuel performance. Companies and research institutions are focusing on scaling up photobioreactor systems, which offer controlled environments for algae cultivation, enabling consistent and large-scale biomass production. There is also a growing trend of collaborations between the aviation industry, governments, and biofuel producers, aiming to meet the rising demand for SAF while adhering to sustainability regulations. Furthermore, the market is experiencing a shift toward integrating algae biofuels into hybrid systems, where they can be blended with conventional jet fuels, helping to ease the transition to cleaner aviation fuels. As regulatory support for sustainable fuels intensifies, microalgae-based jet fuel is expected to play a more prominent role in the decarbonization of the aviation industry.

What is the Country-Wise Analysis of the Sustainable Jet Fuel Microalgae Market?

The sustainable jet fuel microalgae market is growing rapidly in key regions including the USA, China, the UK, Japan, and India. This growth is largely driven by the need to reduce greenhouse gas emissions in the aviation industry and the increasing demand for renewable and environmentally friendly fuel alternatives. Microalgae-based jet fuel is considered a promising solution due to its potential for high energy output and minimal environmental impact. Each of these countries is focusing on expanding their renewable energy infrastructure, and sustainable jet fuel made from microalgae is being seen as a critical component in transitioning to a more sustainable aviation sector. Market dynamics in these regions are influenced by local government policies, technological advancements in biofuel production, and the increasing demand for greener solutions in the aviation industry.

Country CAGR 2026 to 2036 USA 14.8% China 18.1% UK 13.9% Japan 12.7% India 17.3%

What is Driving the Growth of the Sustainable Jet Fuel Microalgae Market in the USA?

The sustainable jet fuel microalgae market in the USA is expanding at a CAGR of 14.8%. This growth is driven by significant investments in renewable energy and biofuels, as the country strives to meet carbon reduction targets set by both government and industry bodies. The aviation sector in the USA is increasingly turning to sustainable fuel sources to address environmental concerns, particularly in light of rising fuel emissions. Microalgae-based jet fuel, with its high energy content and lower carbon footprint, is seen as a viable alternative to traditional fossil fuels. Research and development in biofuel technologies, coupled with supportive government incentives for renewable energy, are expected to drive further growth in the market, positioning the USA as a key player in the global sustainable jet fuel sector.

How is the Sustainable Jet Fuel Microalgae Market Performing in China?

China’s sustainable jet fuel microalgae market is growing rapidly with a CAGR of 18.1%. As one of the world’s largest aviation markets, China is heavily investing in sustainable aviation fuel technologies. The country is actively pursuing the development of biofuels, particularly microalgae-based jet fuel, to reduce its dependency on traditional fossil fuels and lower its carbon emissions. China’s government has introduced various initiatives to support the growth of biofuels, including financial incentives and research grants for biofuel production. Additionally, as China continues to focus on environmental sustainability in all sectors, the aviation industry is shifting towards more sustainable fuel alternatives. The strong growth rate in China is indicative of the country's ambition to become a leader in green aviation solutions.

What Factors are Shaping the Sustainable Jet Fuel Microalgae Market in the UK?

The sustainable jet fuel microalgae market in the UK is expanding at a CAGR of 13.9%. The UK government has made significant strides in setting ambitious carbon reduction goals, which includes a strong push for sustainable aviation fuel. The UK aviation industry is under increasing pressure to meet stringent environmental regulations, and microalgae-based jet fuel offers a promising solution. Research and innovation in algae-based fuel technologies have accelerated in the UK, with several initiatives aimed at scaling up biofuel production. The aviation sector is seeing increased investment in renewable fuel options, and the UK’s leadership in clean energy technology is further driving the adoption of microalgae-based jet fuel as part of its broader efforts to achieve sustainability targets.

What is Contributing to the Growth of the Sustainable Jet Fuel Microalgae Market in Japan?

Japan’s sustainable jet fuel microalgae market is growing steadily, with a CAGR of 12.7%. Japan has been proactive in its efforts to reduce carbon emissions, and the aviation sector is increasingly exploring renewable fuel options, including microalgae-based jet fuel. With government support for the development of biofuels, Japan’s aviation industry is seeking alternative fuels to reduce its environmental impact. Japan’s emphasis on technological innovation, alongside the global shift towards more sustainable energy sources, positions the country well for the adoption of microalgae-based jet fuel. As Japan moves towards greener aviation practices, the market for sustainable jet fuel is expected to continue growing, with key players investing in biofuel research and production technologies.

What Factors Are Driving the Growth of the Sustainable Jet Fuel Microalgae Market in India?

The sustainable jet fuel microalgae market in India is growing at a CAGR of 17.3%. As the country faces rising demand for air travel, reducing aviation-related carbon emissions has become a priority. India’s government has introduced policies to support the development and use of sustainable aviation fuel, including microalgae-based jet fuel. The Indian aviation sector is increasingly looking to adopt biofuels to meet both domestic and international environmental standards. With India’s commitment to achieving its sustainability goals, the demand for microalgae-based jet fuel is expected to grow rapidly. The country’s burgeoning biofuel industry and its focus on renewable energy solutions are contributing to the expansion of the sustainable jet fuel market in India.

What is the Competitive Landscape for the Sustainable Jet Fuel Microalgae Market?

The sustainable jet fuel microalgae market is highly competitive, with major oil and energy companies leading the charge in the development of alternative fuels. ExxonMobil, through its Algae Biofuels joint venture, stands at the forefront of this market, focusing on algae-based biofuels as a renewable and sustainable solution for aviation. The company's significant investments in research and development, coupled with its expertise in large-scale production, have enabled it to maintain a strong market presence. Shell Aviation, with its focus on sustainable fuels, is another key player, working on scalable solutions that address the growing demand for low-carbon alternatives in the aviation sector. Total Energies is also investing in sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) programs, aiming to reduce the carbon footprint of air travel. Similarly, Lanza Tech and its subsidiary Lanza Jet, through their algae-based SAF partnerships, focus on developing cost-effective and environmentally friendly jet fuels. Other companies, including Air Company, are contributing to the market by utilizing innovative technologies to produce sustainable fuels from renewable resources, further intensifying competition.

In the sustainable jet fuel microalgae market, companies adopt a variety of strategies to maintain a competitive edge. Innovation in production processes is a key area of focus, with many firms working to scale algae biofuel production efficiently and economically. ExxonMobil’s partnership approach, combining its technological expertise with research-driven collaborations, is central to its strategy. Shell Aviation’s efforts in sustainable fuel development are aimed at securing long-term supply agreements with airlines, focusing on meeting regulatory requirements and reducing aviation sector emissions. Total Energies and LanzaTech are pursuing similar strategies, emphasizing partnerships with key stakeholders in the aviation industry and government to promote the adoption of SAF. Air Company leverages unique processes to capture carbon and convert it into sustainable fuel, further diversifying the solutions available in the market. These strategies, combined with the increasing demand for environmentally responsible fuels, are expected to drive market growth and solidify the positions of these companies in the competitive landscape of sustainable jet fuel microalgae.

title: Greenstock pre-treatment facility project in Amsterdam enters… - Oils & Fats International
description:
The Greenstock pre-treatment (GPF) facility project in Amsterdam led by energy storage and infrastructure company VTTI and renewable feedstocks trader Connex has entered the front-end engineering design (FEED) phase.
“In partnership with Connex, we are expanding Europe’s access to sustainable feedstocks and enabling the growth of low-carbon fuels.
The facility will reinforce Amsterdam’s role as a hub for sustainable fuels,” said Quinten van Dam Merrett, senior vice president at VTTI Netherlands.
During this phase, the project team would develop the basic engineering of the assets, further refining the facility’s technical design, equipment specifications and construction strategy.
Headquartered in Rotterdam, Connex trades renewable feedstocks such as animal fats, UCO, brown grease and other advanced waste and residue streams for use in the production of renewable diesel and SAF.
text:
The Greenstock pre-treatment (GPF) facility project in Amsterdam led by energy storage and infrastructure company VTTI and renewable feedstocks trader Connex has entered the front-end engineering design (FEED) phase.

Scheduled to become operational in 2029, the facility at VTTI’s terminal in Amsterdam would have a processing capacity of over 400,000 tonnes/year of renewable feedstocks, enabling the production of sustainable fuels, including hydro-treated vegetable oil (HVO) and sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) from both standalone and co-processing units, the companies said on 10 December.

The facility would provide customers in Europe with aggregation, blending and pre-treatment capabilities for waste and residue-based feedstocks, including animal fats category 1, 2 and 3, used cooking oil (UCO) and advanced oils and fats, the companies said.

“In partnership with Connex, we are expanding Europe’s access to sustainable feedstocks and enabling the growth of low-carbon fuels. The facility will reinforce Amsterdam’s role as a hub for sustainable fuels,” said Quinten van Dam Merrett, senior vice president at VTTI Netherlands.

The companies said the FEED phase marked a critical milestone in the project’s progression towards construction and commissioning.

During this phase, the project team would develop the basic engineering of the assets, further refining the facility’s technical design, equipment specifications and construction strategy. the companies said.

During the FEED phase, the companies said they would focus on working closely with local authorities, partnering with technology providers and engineering companies, securing contracts with customers and ensuring compliance with all environmental requirements.

Headquartered in Rotterdam, Connex trades renewable feedstocks such as animal fats, UCO, brown grease and other advanced waste and residue streams for use in the production of renewable diesel and SAF.

Also based in Rotterdam, VTTI develops and operates energy infrastructure, including energy storage terminals, renewable natural gas (RNG) facilities and liquefied natural gas (LNG) regasification terminals.

title: Biobased chemicals face a fraught year - C&EN
description:
The world of biobased chemicals will be tumultuous in 2026.
The year is likely to be rough for many companies commercializing biobased chemicals and fuels, according to Jim Flatt, CEO of DMC Biotechnologies.
Flatt said biobased chemicals will have an easier time than sustainable fuels because the sector enjoys fewer federal subsidies.
He said he’s always urged his bioeconomy peers to have business plans that benefit from subsidies but don’t require them.
Even as subsidies wane, some biobased fuel firms will also advance in 2026.
text:
The world of biobased chemicals will be tumultuous in 2026. In some corners, new technology platforms will emerge, and companies will start to produce meaningful volumes. In other corners, start-ups and projects will falter and fall as an uncertain policy environment scares off investors, especially in the US.

The year is likely to be rough for many companies commercializing biobased chemicals and fuels, according to Jim Flatt, CEO of DMC Biotechnologies. The US government has pulled sharply away from supporting cleantech, and many consumer-facing firms that were interested in the environmental benefits of biobased feedstocks are backing away from their sustainability goals in response.

Flatt said biobased chemicals will have an easier time than sustainable fuels because the sector enjoys fewer federal subsidies. He said he’s always urged his bioeconomy peers to have business plans that benefit from subsidies but don’t require them. “The companies that make it through this will have the ability to thrive.”

DMC, one of C&EN’s 10 Start-Ups to Watch in 2022, said at the Alternative Fuels and Chemicals Coalition’s recent annual meeting in Washington, DC, that this year, it will start selling myo-inositol to the nutraceutical market at a scale of hundreds of metric tons and L-alanine to cleaning-product makers at thousands of metric tons. DMC installs metabolic switches in fermentation microbes so that operators can toggle between growth and production phases with simple chemical cues.

Other firms are doing this kind of biosynthesis outside the cell. One start-up that even pulls its name from the idea is eXoZymes. Chief Commercial Officer Damien Perriman said at the meeting that he hopes the name is so clear it gets genericized, like Kleenex or Dumpster, as a shorthand for the concept. The firm is using artificial intelligence along with reams of public and private protein-structure data to reengineer natural enzymes so they are stable and efficient in a reactor instead of a cell.

Part of the appeal of cell-free biosynthesis is not having to tend to the needs of a complex, living organism to keep reactors running, said Alex Rosay, CEO of Cascade Biocatalysts. Rosay’s start-up immobilizes and protects enzymes within polymer brushes affixed to tiny silica beads. The enzymes still need some babying, such as a steady supply of cofactors or metal ions, but all the sugar or other biochemical fuel goes to the desired reaction instead of being split between chemical production and cellular reproduction.

Even as subsidies wane, some biobased fuel firms will also advance in 2026. Nearly all the biofuels on the market today are made by upgrading used vegetable oil, but the supply of that feedstock is nearly all spoken for, according to Keith Gillard, CEO of Sustaero. The firm is converting old wood pulp mills to make syngas and liquid fuels instead of paper; its first plant is scheduled to come on line in 2029.

The alcohol-to-jet fuel company Gevo, meanwhile, expects to approve a final investment decision this year on a plant in North Dakota that would make 114 million L per year of sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) from ethanol. Other routes to SAF are progressing too, such as Captis Aire’s thermochemical process to make the fuel from wood-waste terpenes and Twelve’s electrolysis stack that makes it from carbon dioxide via carbon monoxide. Captis Aire has sold a full barrel of fuel from its pilot plant in Arizona, and Twelve is constructing a demonstration-scale plant in Washington State.

These investments aside, a US policy environment that is unfriendly now and uncertain for the future will push bioeconomy investment dollars overseas, predicted Joanne Ivancic, executive director of the advocacy nonprofit Advanced BioFuels USA. China is rapidly adding the renewable electricity infrastructure that’s needed to produce low-carbon fuels and chemicals, Europe is enacting policies that mandate the use of biobased and circular feedstocks, and global consumer demand for sustainable products is growing every year.

Investors won’t stop trying to capitalize on the sustainability megatrend just because the US market has become inhospitable for cleantech, Ivancic said. Instead, they’ll look elsewhere for projects they can invest in safely.

title: Chamber welcomes Phillips 66 acquisition of Prax Lindsey Oil Refinery
description:
THE Hull & Humber Chamber of Commerce has welcomed Phillips 66 announcement that it has agreed to acquire the Lindsey Oil Refinery following its closure in June 2025, subject to various conditions and regulatory clearances being met.
The move marks a significant step in Phillips 66’s long-term growth strategy which, according to the company statement, will integrate the assets of Prax Lindsey Oil Refinery into the Humber Refinery.
It will strengthen the Humber Refinery, bolster the local economy, and protect thousands of jobs across the supply chain as the Humber Refinery continues to produce sustainable aviation fuel, graphite coke for electric vehicle battery manufacturing, petrochemical feedstocks and transportation fuels.
The company said: “We understand that many hoped the Lindsey Oil Refinery would continue as a fully operational refinery.
We hope as many people as possible will be able to find work within the expanded Phillips 66 refinery operations”.
text:
THE Hull & Humber Chamber of Commerce has welcomed Phillips 66 announcement that it has agreed to acquire the Lindsey Oil Refinery following its closure in June 2025, subject to various conditions and regulatory clearances being met.

The move marks a significant step in Phillips 66’s long-term growth strategy which, according to the company statement, will integrate the assets of Prax Lindsey Oil Refinery into the Humber Refinery. This will help to preserve the UK’s remaining vital refining capacity, safeguard critical fuel supply chains, and support high-quality employment locally.

A Phillips 66 spokesman said: “This acquisition will preserve existing jobs at the Humber Refinery and support hundreds of quality jobs through the integration of the assets.

“This investment is about growth. It will strengthen the Humber Refinery, bolster the local economy, and protect thousands of jobs across the supply chain as the Humber Refinery continues to produce sustainable aviation fuel, graphite coke for electric vehicle battery manufacturing, petrochemical feedstocks and transportation fuels.

The company said: “We understand that many hoped the Lindsey Oil Refinery would continue as a fully operational refinery. Unfortunately, due to the limitations of its scale, facilities and capabilities, our evaluations have confirmed the refinery in its current form is not viable. The liquidators and Official Receiver have also confirmed that no viable bids were received that would have resulted in a return to refining operations, allowing all Prax employees to be retained.

Commenting on behalf of the Chamber of Commerce, David Hooper, said: “We are pleased to see Phillips 66 acquire the Prax site which will help to secure the future of Phillips 66 in the Humber, but there are still concerns around the remaining jobs which are only guaranteed until March. We hope as many people as possible will be able to find work within the expanded Phillips 66 refinery operations”.

title: IATA warns SAF mandates in EU and UK fail to boost sustainable aviation fuel production
description:
IATA warns SAF mandates in EU and UK fail to boost sustainable aviation fuel production IATA reports SAF production reached 1.9 million tonnes in 2025, criticises EU and UK mandates for limiting supply and raising costs for airlines.
The International Air Transport Association (IATA) has released updated estimates for Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) production, highlighting challenges in scaling the industry.
In 2025, SAF output is expected to reach 1.9 million tonnes (2.4 billion litres), double the 1 million tonnes produced in 2024.
“SAF production growth fell short of expectations as poorly designed mandates stalled momentum in the fledgling SAF industry.
If the goal of SAF mandates was to slow progress and increase prices, policymakers knocked it out of the park.
text:
IATA warns SAF mandates in EU and UK fail to boost sustainable aviation fuel production

IATA reports SAF production reached 1.9 million tonnes in 2025, criticises EU and UK mandates for limiting supply and raising costs for airlines.

The International Air Transport Association (IATA) has released updated estimates for Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) production, highlighting challenges in scaling the industry. In 2025, SAF output is expected to reach 1.9 million tonnes (2.4 billion litres), double the 1 million tonnes produced in 2024. Growth is projected to slow in 2026, reaching 2.4 million tonnes. Despite this increase, SAF will account for only 0.6 per cent of total jet fuel consumption in 2025, rising to 0.8 per cent in 2026. At current prices, the SAF premium will add approximately USD 3.6 billion in fuel costs for the airline industry in 2025.

The downward revision from earlier forecasts reflects insufficient policy support to fully utilise installed SAF capacities. SAF costs exceed conventional jet fuel by a factor of two, and by up to five in mandated markets.

“SAF production growth fell short of expectations as poorly designed mandates stalled momentum in the fledgling SAF industry. If the goal of SAF mandates was to slow progress and increase prices, policymakers knocked it out of the park. But if the objective is to increase SAF production to further the decarbonisation of aviation, then they need to learn from failure and work with the airline industry to design incentives that will work,” said Willie Walsh, IATA’s Director General.

Mandates in the EU and UK have failed to accelerate SAF production and adoption. In Europe, ReFuelEU Aviation has sharply increased costs amid limited SAF capacity and oligopolistic supply chains. Fuel suppliers have raised profit margins so that airlines pay up to five times the price of conventional jet fuel and double the market price of SAF, without guaranteeing supply or consistent documentation. In the UK, SAF mandates have also triggered price spikes, forcing airlines to absorb significant costs. In total, airlines paid a premium of USD 2.9 billion for the limited 1.9 million tonnes of SAF available in 2025.

“Europe’s fragmented policies distort markets, slow investment, and undermine efforts to scale SAF production. Europe’s regulators must recognise that its approach is not working and urgently correct course. The recent European Commission STIP announcement is a step forward though it lacks a clear timeline. Actions, not words, are what matter,” said Walsh.

The shortfall in SAF supply will force many airlines to review their 2030 SAF commitments. “Regrettably, many airlines that have committed to use 10 per cent SAF by 2030 will be forced to reevaluate these commitments. SAF is not being produced in sufficient amounts to enable these airlines to achieve their ambition. These commitments were made in good faith but simply cannot be delivered,” said Walsh.

With e-SAF mandates approaching in the UK (2028) and EU (2030), policymakers must avoid repeating previous mistakes. “Given the low SAF production volumes, it is evident that current policies are not having the desired effect. Faced with such facts, regulators must course-correct, ensure the long-term viability of SAF production, and achieve scale so that costs can come down. Mandates have done just the opposite, and it is outrageous to repeat the same mistakes with e-SAF mandates,” said Marie Owens Thomsen, IATA’s Senior Vice President for Sustainability and Chief Economist.

title: EcoCeres earns China's SAF export recognition and airworthiness certificate
description:
EcoCeres has announced that its wholly-owned subsidiary, ECO Biochemical Technology (Zhangjiagang) Company Limited (ECO BioTech), has been included in the official China SAF export “White List” and awarded China’s airworthiness certificate.
To date, only a handful of producers have been included in the China SAF export White List or have received China’s airworthiness certificate – ECO BioTech proudly among them.
The combined achievements of being recognised on China’s SAF Export “White List” and obtaining the airworthiness certificate demonstrate EcoCeres’ strong technical expertise, outstanding product quality, and unwavering commitment to aviation safety.
Together, these milestones validate that EcoCeres’ SAF production and quality assurance.
This will support efforts in China and across the global aviation industry to reduce lifecycle carbon emissions and achieve long‑term climate targets.
text:
EcoCeres has announced that its wholly-owned subsidiary, ECO Biochemical Technology (Zhangjiagang) Company Limited (ECO BioTech), has been included in the official China SAF export “White List” and awarded China’s airworthiness certificate.

These recognitions confirm EcoCeres’ compliance with aviation safety standards for both domestic and international markets, as well as the operational reliability standards set by local authorities.

To date, only a handful of producers have been included in the China SAF export White List or have received China’s airworthiness certificate – ECO BioTech proudly among them. While these qualifications are formally granted to ECO BioTech, they collectively reinforce EcoCeres’ standing position as a trusted provider of sustainable aviation fuel solutions from Asia to the global market.

The combined achievements of being recognised on China’s SAF Export “White List” and obtaining the airworthiness certificate demonstrate EcoCeres’ strong technical expertise, outstanding product quality, and unwavering commitment to aviation safety.

Together, these milestones validate that EcoCeres’ SAF production and quality assurance. This recognition not only reinforces EcoCeres’ reliability as a SAF producer but also enables the company to expand supply channels from China to domestic and global airlines and fuel partners, accelerating its growth and positioning EcoCeres as a trusted contributor to decarbonising global aviation.

“We are deeply grateful to the Mainland Chinese authorities and all the relevant departments and experts for their support and guidance throughout the rigorous process leading to these dual recognitions,” said Matti Lievonen, CEO of EcoCeres.

“Building on this strong foundation, we look forward to working with our partners to drive broader adoption of SAF in both Chinese and international markets, helping to accelerate the development of the SAF ecosystem in China and advance global decarbonisation in aviation.”

With these new qualifications, EcoCeres plans to deepen collaboration with domestic and international airlines, fuel distributors and other value‑chain partners to expand the availability of SAF produced in China to key aviation hubs at home and abroad. This will support efforts in China and across the global aviation industry to reduce lifecycle carbon emissions and achieve long‑term climate targets.

description:

Competitive Landscape of the Sustainable Jet Fuel Microalgae Market The competitive landscape features an uneasy alliance between global energy supermajors, biotechnology startups, and national research entities.
text:
Sustainable Jet Fuel Microalgae Market Forecast and Outlook 2026 to 2036

The global market for sustainable jet fuel derived from microalgae is projected to ascend from USD 1.62 billion in 2026 to USD 4.68 billion by 2036, accelerating at an 11.2% CAGR. This growth is propelled by the aviation sector's legally binding commitment to net-zero emissions and the subsequent inadequacy of current waste- and crop-based feedstocks to meet future demand at scale. Microalgae presents a nonpareil solution, offering exponential yield per acre without competing for arable land or freshwater, while simultaneously sequestering industrial CO2.

Key Takeaways from the Sustainable Jet Fuel Microalgae Market

Market Value for 2026: USD 1.62 Billion

Market Value for 2036: USD 4.68 Billion

Forecast CAGR (2026 to 2036): 11.2%

Leading Feedstock Type Segment (2026): Nannochloropsis spp. (28%)

Leading Technology Route Segment (2026): Hydrothermal Liquefaction (38%)

Leading End Use Segment (2026): Commercial Aviation (56%)

Key Growth Countries: China (18.10% CAGR), India (17.30% CAGR), USA (14.80% CAGR), UK (13.90% CAGR), Japan (12.70% CAGR)

Key Players in the Market: ExxonMobil (Algae Biofuels JV), Shell Aviation (Sustainable Fuels), TotalEnergies (SAF Programs), LanzaTech/LanzaJet (Algal SAF Partner)

The market is transitioning from pilot-scale validation to the first wave of commercial biorefinery investments, driven by offtake agreements from airlines seeking to secure long-term, scalable supplies of low-carbon fuel. The staggering 18.10% CAGR in China underscores a national strategy to dominate the green industrial value chain, leveraging algae cultivation as part of a broader carbon capture and utilization ecosystem.

Success is no longer defined by laboratory lipid yields but by the integration of biology with industrial engineering, creating robust, continuous cultivation systems and cost-effective downstream processing that can reliably produce drop-in hydrocarbons compatible with global aviation infrastructure. This market represents the critical bridge between decarbonization mandates and the technical reality of powering global flight, making algae not merely an alternative fuel but a strategic commodity for energy security in a carbon-constrained future.

Metric

Metric Value Market Value (2026) USD 1.62 Billion Market Forecast Value (2036) USD 4.68 Billion Forecast CAGR (2026 to 2036) 11.2%

Category

Category Segments Feedstock Type Nannochloropsis spp., Chlorella spp., Spirulina spp., Mixed/Engineered Strains, Others Technology Route Hydrothermal Liquefaction, Transesterification + Upgrading, Pyrolysis & Catalytic Cracking, Gasification-Based Routes, Others End Use Commercial Aviation, Military Aviation, Business & General Aviation, Others Region North America, Latin America, Western Europe, Eastern Europe, East Asia, South Asia & Pacific, MEA

Segmental Analysis

By Feedstock Type, Which Strain Balances High Lipid Content with Cultivation Robustness?

Nannochloropsis spp. leads the segment with a 28% share. This genus is favored for its naturally high lipid yield, particularly triglycerides suitable for fuel conversion, and its resilience in varied cultivation conditions, including saline water.

Its predominance reflects a focus on strains that provide a strong baseline economic potential for lipid-per-acre metrics. The extensive research history and genetic tractability of Nannochloropsis also allow for further strain improvement through engineering, positioning it as a foundational organism for the first generation of commercial algae-to-jet fuel operations.

By Technology Route, Which Process Best Handles Wet Biomass and Delivers High-Qield Hydrocarbons?

Hydrothermal liquefaction is the leading technology at 38%. HTL’s advantage lies in its ability to process wet algae biomass directly, eliminating the energy-intensive drying step—a major cost hurdle. It efficiently converts the entire biomass, including proteins and carbohydrates, into a crude bio-oil that can be catalytically upgraded to jet-range hydrocarbons.

This whole-biomass utilization and compatibility with high-moisture feedstock make HTL the most promising pathway for achieving the necessary economic and energy balance for commercial scale, attracting significant R&D and pilot investment.

By End Use, Which Sector Provides the Anchor Demand and Willingness to Pay a Premium?

Commercial aviation is the dominant end-use segment, accounting for 56% of demand. Airlines are under the most intense regulatory and public pressure to decarbonize, facing mandates like the EU’s ReFuelEU and CORSIA. Their large, centralized fuel needs provide the volume necessary to justify large-scale biorefinery investments.

The sector’s ability to absorb a cost premium through sustainability surcharges or blended ticket prices creates the initial market pull, making commercial aviation the essential first customer for scaling microalgae SAF production.

What are the Drivers, Restraints, and Key Trends of the Sustainable Jet Fuel Microalgae Market?

Factor Type Elaboration Regulatory Blending Mandates Driver Policies like ReFuelEU legally require increasing SAF volumes, creating guaranteed demand and de-risking production investments. Capital Intensity & System Integration Restraint The need for massive photobioreactors or pond systems, plus downstream refining, requires billion-dollar investments and untested scale-up. Integration with Carbon Capture Trend Co-locating algae farms with industrial emitters (e.g., cement plants) transforms a cost center (CO2) into a feedstock, improving economics and LCA.

Analysis of the Sustainable Jet Fuel Microalgae Market by Key Countries

Country CAGR (2026 to 2036) China 18.10% India 17.30% USA 14.80% UK 13.90% Japan 12.70%

How is China's Command-Driven Industrial Ecology and Carbon Neutrality Pledge Catalyzing Scale?

China's leading 18.10% CAGR is a function of its state-capitalist model, where national carbon neutrality goals directly translate into targeted funding and pilot projects. Algae cultivation is strategically linked to industrial carbon capture from its vast manufacturing base.

The government can mandate pilot partnerships between state-owned energy giants, airlines, and research institutes, rapidly iterating and scaling integrated systems with a focus on controlling the entire technological value chain for future export.

What is the Impact of India's Focus on Energy Security and Non-Arable Land Utilization?

India's 17.30% growth is driven by its imperative for energy import independence and the strategic use of its extensive non-arable land and coastline. National programs promote algae cultivation as a means to produce biofuel without impacting food security.

The growth is characterized by a focus on developing low-cost, open-pond cultivation systems resilient to local climatic conditions and on leveraging India's strong biotechnology sector for strain development.

Why is the USA's Blend of Policy, Venture Capital, and Airline Offtake Agreements a Key Factor?

A powerful mix supports the USA’s 14.80% growth: the Inflation Reduction Act's production tax credits for SAF, a deep pool of venture capital for hard-tech bio-innovation, and proactive offtake deals from major US airlines.

This ecosystem allows for multiple technology pathways to be pursued in parallel, from startups focusing on novel strains to oil majors scaling HTL technology, all competing to deliver cost-competitive fuel to a ready and incentivized market.

How is the UK's Legislative Leadership and Focus on Synthetic Fuels Pathway Shaping Its Role?

The UK's 13.90% CAGR stems from its early and aggressive legislative targets for SAF uptake, including a revenue certainty mechanism. This policy environment attracts project finance.

The UK’s technical focus often aligns with gasification-based pathways, viewing algae as a biomass source for synthesis gas that can be funneled into established Fischer-Tropsch processes to produce certified jet fuel, aiming for technological compatibility with other waste biomass streams.

What Role does Japan's Technological Sophistication and Geopolitical Resource Strategy Play?

Japan's 12.70% growth is underpinned by its advanced biotechnology and engineering capabilities, applied to a national strategy of securing alternative energy resources. With limited domestic fossil fuels, Japan invests in algae as a technologically intensive, high-yield renewable resource that can be cultivated domestically or via overseas projects. The focus is on high-efficiency closed photobioreactor systems and maximizing value extraction from every ton of biomass.

Competitive Landscape of the Sustainable Jet Fuel Microalgae Market

The competitive landscape features an uneasy alliance between global energy supermajors, biotechnology startups, and national research entities. Energy companies bring crucial scaling capital, refining expertise, and access to distribution, while biotech firms contribute proprietary strains and novel cultivation technologies.

Competition centers on securing intellectual property around high-productivity algal strains and efficient conversion processes, and most critically, on forming alliances with airlines for long-term offtake agreements that can finance the construction of first-of-their-kind commercial facilities. Success is measured by the ability to move from pilot volumes to delivering thousands of barrels per day under a binding contract.

Likely Scenarios for Market Expansion

Scenario Description Vertical Integration Scenario An oil major partners with a biotech firm to build an integrated facility, controlling the supply chain from strain to fuel to achieve cost leadership and secure exclusive airline deals. Technology Licensing Model A technology developer licenses its proprietary cultivation or conversion process to global partners, accelerating deployment and generating revenue without bearing full capital costs. Consortium-Based Build-Out Airlines form a consortium to co-finance a dedicated production plant, transforming from fuel offtakers to equity investors to guarantee supply and manage costs. Government-Backed National Champion A state-directed enterprise leverages policy support, low-cost resources, and regulatory advantages to scale domestic production for both local use and export.

title: DHL says on track toward net-zero goal by 2050 - PortCalls Asia
description:
In 2025, the company advanced several key levers of its sustainability strategy, including scaling sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) to electrifying last‑mile delivery and building solar‑powered infrastructure, the company said in a media release.
In the Philippines, DHL entered into a strategic partnership with the Gokongwei Group, focusing on greenhouse gas emissions-reduced logistics solutions.
READ: DHL, Gokongwei Group ink partnership on green logistics solutions For aviation, DHL signed one of its largest-ever SAF agreements with Phillips 66, which involves over 240,000 metric tons (approximately 314 million liters) of SAF over three years.
As such, DHL has been actively testing hydrogen trucks in Europe, North America and Asia Pacific, and will now introduce them in the Middle East.
Last year, DHL signed an memorandum of understanding with Hyperview in Saudi Arabia to pilot hydrogen-powered trucks.
text:
The DHL Group said it is on track with its net-zero goal by 2050, citing five key achievements in its global decarbonization journey last year

One of last year’s milestones was setting up solar-powered warehousing in Asia

For aviation, DHL signed one of its largest-ever sustainable aviation fuel agreements with Phillips 66

DHL also partnered with CMA CGM to purchase 8,800 metric tons of UCOME second-generation biofuel

For land transport, DHL signed an memorandum of understanding with Hyperview in Saudi Arabia to pilot hydrogen-powered trucks

DHL is also aiming to electrify 66% of its last-mile fleet by 2030, with Germany leading the charge

The DHL Group said it is on track with its net-zero goal by 2050, citing five key achievements in its global decarbonization journey last year.

In 2025, the company advanced several key levers of its sustainability strategy, including scaling sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) to electrifying last‑mile delivery and building solar‑powered infrastructure, the company said in a media release.

“These achievements mark meaningful progress toward DHL’s goal of net‑zero greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions by 2050 and reinforce its role in building more sustainable, efficient, and resilient global trade,” it said.

One of last year’s milestones was setting up solar-powered warehousing in Asia and continuing to explore facilities that produce or source renewable energy on-site, combining sustainability with energy self-sufficiency.

DHL launched a solar-powered warehouse in Thailand that is expected to generate 100% of its energy on-site through a 4.2 MWp solar array and advanced battery storage. This facility eliminates reliance on fossil-based grid electricity and sets a blueprint for future logistics infrastructure worldwide.

In the Philippines, DHL entered into a strategic partnership with the Gokongwei Group, focusing on greenhouse gas emissions-reduced logistics solutions.

READ: DHL, Gokongwei Group ink partnership on green logistics solutions

For aviation, DHL signed one of its largest-ever SAF agreements with Phillips 66, which involves over 240,000 metric tons (approximately 314 million liters) of SAF over three years.

READ: Air cargo demand remains strong fueled by e-commerce

This will reduce lifecycle emissions by approximately 737,000 metric tons of CO2e – about the same impact as 2,400 one-way flights from Los Angeles to Frankfurt, DHL said.

The fuel, produced in California, will primarily serve DHL’s West Coast operations.

At sea – where most global goods are moved, making sustainable marine fuel critical for reducing emissions – DHL said it has partnered with CMA CGM to purchase 8,800 metric tons of UCOME second-generation biofuel, enabling an estimated 25,000 metric tons of CO₂e emissions reduction on a well-to-wake basis (covering the full lifecycle of fuel emissions).

“That is roughly equivalent to powering a large container ship for several days of operation. This collaboration demonstrates a significant step for low-carbon maritime transport,” DHL said.

On land, hydrogen-powered trucks are emerging as a solution for decarbonizing long-haul logistics, providing longer range than electric trucks. As such, DHL has been actively testing hydrogen trucks in Europe, North America and Asia Pacific, and will now introduce them in the Middle East.

Last year, DHL signed an memorandum of understanding with Hyperview in Saudi Arabia to pilot hydrogen-powered trucks. DHL is also aiming to electrify 66% of its last-mile fleet – the final step of getting a shipment to the end customer – by 2030, with Germany leading the charge.

The company also announced one of its largest electric‑vehicle purchases in 2025 consisting of 2,400 new Ford electric vans for its Post & Parcel Germany division, the majority of which have already been delivered and are in operation.

READ: DHL enhances EV, battery supply chain solutions

title: MASH Makes powers vessel trial using drop-in biofuel from a carbon-negative process
description:
MASH Makes’ upgraded CNSL fuel has passed a critical lab engine test that confirms its readiness for marine use without the reliability issues traditionally associated with CNSL-based fuels.
In recent years, CNSL, a fuel made from cashew nut shell liquid (CNSL), emerged as a promising, but at times unreliable alternative to existing biofuels.
But now, through a proprietary upgrading process, MASH Makes developed a CNSL-based fuel that is clean-burning, stable, and suitable for commercial shipping.
The tested blend — 20% Upgraded CNSL and80% VLSFO — was evaluated at FVTR GmbH using a marinegrade single cylinder research engine.
“This result proves that with the right upgrading process, CNSL can become a serious contender in marine fuels,” said MASH Makes head of research and development Krishna Chakravarty.
text:
MASH Makes’ upgraded CNSL fuel has passed a critical lab engine test that confirms its readiness for marine use without the reliability issues traditionally associated with CNSL-based fuels.

In recent years, CNSL, a fuel made from cashew nut shell liquid (CNSL), emerged as a promising, but at times unreliable alternative to existing biofuels. Its tendency to polymerise and inability to reliably blend has been a cause of frustration among shipowners. This sticky characteristic isn’t surprising, though, given that it is traditionally used as a resin to thicken paint.

But now, through a proprietary upgrading process, MASH Makes developed a CNSL-based fuel that is clean-burning, stable, and suitable for commercial shipping.

The tested blend — 20% Upgraded CNSL and80% VLSFO — was evaluated at FVTR GmbH using a marinegrade single cylinder research engine. The fuel showed clean combustion, No injector fouling or residueand Stable operation across all loads, with no tuning or pressure adjustments required.

“The upgraded CNSL fuel from MASH Makes performed reliably across all tested loads, showing clean injection behaviour and no signs of degradation,” said Robert Bank, the team lead for team lead fuels and component analyses at FVTR.

“From a technical standpoint, it behaved comparably to conventional marine fuels.”

The upgraded CNSL also showed improved emissions compared to earlier blends: NOx slightly increased but stayed within IMO Tier II limits, CO levels remained stable, indicating good combustion and smoke decreasedat partial loads and increased only slightly at full load.

This test represents a key milestone in making CNSL a viable and scalable commercial fuel for shipping.

“This result proves that with the right upgrading process, CNSL can become a serious contender in marine fuels,” said MASH Makes head of research and development Krishna Chakravarty. “It’s cost-effective, scalable, and doesn’t require fossil infrastructure changes. With our tech and learnings, we’re enabling the development of new effective biofuel solutions.”

text:
Malaysia Airlines is pushing hard to make sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) a regular part of its operations and not just a one-off PR flight.

The carrier has moved from trial runs to formal partnerships, corporate offerings and involvement with national policy work, signalling it sees SAF as central to cutting its carbon footprint rather than a symbolic gesture.

Demo flights and early partnerships

Malaysia Airlines’ public SAF story began with demonstration flights and collaborative deals.

In 2022, the airline operated its first passenger flight using Neste-produced SAF supplied locally by PETRONAS, running a blend derived from waste and residue feedstocks — a practical test that proved both technically and commercially instructive.

That flight was explicitly framed as the first step toward making SAF “the cleaner and more viable energy option for regular flights by 2025”.

From trials to strategy

title: Bunge Brazil secures global first certification for sustainable soybeans used in aviation fuel
description:
Bunge Brazil has received a major sustainability certification for soybeans supplied for the production of Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF), marking an important step in efforts to reduce emissions from air travel, reports Milling Middle East & Africa.
It follows the International Sustainability and Carbon Certification (ISCC) framework used for biofuel raw materials.
These supplies are expected to support SAF producers, including Brazilian airlines and international fuel refiners working toward carbon-neutral flights by 2050.
Brazil has set a target of blending five per cent SAF into aviation fuel by 2030.
With this certification, Bunge becomes the first company worldwide to have soybeans approved under this high-level sustainability standard.
text:
Bunge Brazil has received a major sustainability certification for soybeans supplied for the production of Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF), marking an important step in efforts to reduce emissions from air travel, reports Milling Middle East & Africa.

The certification, announced in late December 2025, confirms that the soybeans meet strict standards for traceability and environmental responsibility throughout the supply chain. It follows the International Sustainability and Carbon Certification (ISCC) framework used for biofuel raw materials.

The certification was granted by SCS Global Services under the ISCC CORSIA PLUS system, which is recognised by the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO). It includes the ISCC CORSIA PLUS Low-LUC seal, which ensures that the soybeans can be traced back to their origin and are produced under strict farming rules.

According to the certification, soybeans processed at the facility carry a low risk of indirect land-use change, a key requirement to ensure that SAF production does not lead to deforestation or environmental damage.

The initiative covers soybeans sourced from Bunge’s operations in the states of Mato Grosso and Goiás. These operations follow zero-deforestation commitments, promote soil-friendly farming methods, and aim to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.

Certified volumes are initially estimated at around 100,000 tonnes. These supplies are expected to support SAF producers, including Brazilian airlines and international fuel refiners working toward carbon-neutral flights by 2050.

Audits carried out as part of the certification confirmed compliance with no-burning practices, improved soil management, and protection of biodiversity.

The certification supports ICAO’s broader CORSIA programme, which requires airlines to cut emissions by using carbon offsets and cleaner fuels such as SAF.

With demand for SAF rising steadily, certified Brazilian soybeans could play an important role for airlines seeking to meet international climate requirements.

The process builds on Bunge’s fully traceable soy supply system, which has been expanded from 80 per cent coverage in the Cerrado region to full traceability. The system uses digital tracking to monitor the supply chain from farms to processing.

The soybeans also meet requirements under the European Union’s deforestation regulation set to take effect in 2026. These include farm location tracking and low-emission farming practices such as reduced soil disturbance and crop rotation.

Brazil, the world’s largest soybean exporter with annual shipments of about 170 million tonnes, is under increasing pressure to ensure sustainable sourcing as new European import rules come into force.

Industry observers say the move places Bunge ahead of competitors such as Cargill and ADM and could allow the company to earn higher prices for soybeans used in aviation fuel.

Global demand for SAF is growing by about 20 per cent each year, driven by ICAO climate policies. Brazil has set a target of blending five per cent SAF into aviation fuel by 2030.

With this certification, Bunge becomes the first company worldwide to have soybeans approved under this high-level sustainability standard. For Brazil, the development highlights the growing role of agriculture not only in food supply but also in supporting cleaner energy solutions to address climate change.

title: Nova Sustainable Fuels Project In Goldboro Approved, Aims To Cut Carbon Emissions And ...
description:
Nova Sustainable Fuels has received environmental assessment approval for the first phase of its renewable energy park project in Goldboro, Guysborough County.
This project will focus on producing sustainable aviation fuel using waste biomass sourced from Nova Scotia’s forestry sector and related forest-based industries.
The initiative aims to provide a low-emission alternative to conventional petroleum-based aviation fuels, contributing to the reduction of carbon emissions.
While the first phase has received approval, Nova Sustainable Fuels will need a second environmental assessment for the project’s proposed second phase.
To ensure environmental protection and public safety, the project must comply with 34 specific terms and conditions outlined in the environmental assessment approval.
text:
Nova Sustainable Fuels has received environmental assessment approval for the first phase of its renewable energy park project in Goldboro, Guysborough County. This project will focus on producing sustainable aviation fuel using waste biomass sourced from Nova Scotia’s forestry sector and related forest-based industries. The initiative aims to provide a low-emission alternative to conventional petroleum-based aviation fuels, contributing to the reduction of carbon emissions.

The project has been recognized for its potential environmental and economic benefits. Timothy Halman, Minister of Environment and Climate Change, emphasized the importance of such initiatives, stating that projects like this play a critical role in lowering global carbon emissions while generating employment opportunities and boosting the local economy. He further highlighted that supporting projects of this nature helps position Nova Scotia as a leader in climate action, innovation, and the global clean energy transition.

While the first phase has received approval, Nova Sustainable Fuels will need a second environmental assessment for the project’s proposed second phase. This phase includes the development of a wind and solar farm, along with a transmission line to supply renewable energy for sustainable fuel production. The project is expected to generate significant employment and economic impact. During the construction phase, approximately 1,000 jobs are anticipated, while operations are expected to sustain up to 80 jobs through the project’s operational life, which is projected to continue until 2081.

In addition, the project is expected to provide direct and indirect economic benefits to local businesses, communities, and residents. To ensure environmental protection and public safety, the project must comply with 34 specific terms and conditions outlined in the environmental assessment approval. These conditions are designed to safeguard both human health and the surrounding environment. Furthermore, the project will require additional approvals, including an industrial permit and a water withdrawal approval, before proceeding.

title: Sustainable Aviation Fuel Agreements - Clean the Sky
description:
Flying Forest, a company developing a new production facility in Finland, and ATOBA Energy, which acts as a specialized intermediary to sell this fuel to airlines, have entered into a preliminary commercial agreement.
The focus falls on increasing the supply of a lower-carbon alternative to conventional jet fuel.
The long-term SAF offtake agreement is said to "support Flying Forest's groundbreaking project in Finland while advancing ATOBA's mission to bridge the gap between SAF producers and airlines."
Flying Forest's facility aims to convert a substantial volume of local forestry by-products — materials like sawmill residues and non-commercial wood that would otherwise have limited use — into sustainable aviation fuel using a methanol-based process.
Image Credit: ATOBA Energy,
text:
Flying Forest, a company developing a new production facility in Finland, and ATOBA Energy, which acts as a specialized intermediary to sell this fuel to airlines, have entered into a preliminary commercial agreement. The focus falls on increasing the supply of a lower-carbon alternative to conventional jet fuel. The long-term SAF offtake agreement is said to "support Flying Forest's groundbreaking project in Finland while advancing ATOBA's mission to bridge the gap between SAF producers and airlines."

Flying Forest's facility aims to convert a substantial volume of local forestry by-products — materials like sawmill residues and non-commercial wood that would otherwise have limited use — into sustainable aviation fuel using a methanol-based process. With a target output of 200,000 tons annually, this represents a meaningful contribution to a market where supply is currently extremely limited.
